Award.AwardTitle: Support for U.S. High Energy Physicists to Attend 45th Rencontres de Moriond Conferences, La Thuile, Italy
Award.AbstractNarration: This grant provides partial support for young physicists to attend either of the two sequential 45th Rencontres de Moriond conferences to be held in La Thuile, Italy: (1) Electroweak Interactions and Unified Theories (March 6-13, 2010) and (2) QCD and High Energy Hadronic Interactions (March 13-20, 2010). Moriond meetings in 2010 are transitional since increasing importance will be placed on the preparation for the LHC physics and commissioning of the detectors, in which the U.S. scientists play a major role. With both experiments being in the full commissioning mode with the first LHC beam data and vast amount of cosmics collected with the fully operational detectors in their underground experimental halls, one expects an increased number of LHC talks at the 2010 Moriond conference. Consequently, the 2010 Moriond remains a unique and excellent opportunity to both advertise the impressive US science program in particle physics and at the same time to give our most talented young scientists extra visibility by allowing them to deliver their latest results at these two major European fora. Special efforts will be made to encourage women and minorities to participate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was for partial support for US scientists to attend Rencontre de Moriond Conferences on: (1) QCD AND HIGH ENERGY HADRONIC INTERACTIONS, and (2) LECTROWEAK INTERACTIONS AND UNIFIED THEORIES. The 43rd Rencontre de Moriond Conference on Electroweak Theory and Unified Theories and the Rencontre de Moriond on QCD AND HIGH ENERGY HADRONIC INTERACTIONS were held in La Thuile, Italy, March 2010.  Due partly to late NSF notification, many of the US participants for 2010 Moriond conferences already had their fundings arranged from other sources. Altogether, approximately $4500 was spent for 2010 Moriond, and an no-cost extension for approximately 5500 was granted for the unspent amount to supplement fundings for those planning to attend 2011 Moriond conference. Altogether, fourteen young US HE were provided partial subsidies over a two-year period.

It has been a success in encouraging and supporting US HE physicists to continue to participate in these annual meetings. All US presentations were well received, and quoted liberally in both the theory and the experimental summary talks.  As in the past, these meetings have provided unique opportunities for US physicists to gain experience presenting scientific talks at major international conferences. These are extremely useful occasions for active us high-energy physicists to meet and discuss HE physics topics of current interests with other international colleagues.

In summary, we emphaisize that this award has helped to maintain a strong US presence at these international HE physics conferences by having a continuing group of active physicists coming on an annual basis. This is important in maintaining the leading role the US HE community has played in the past. More gneerally, this award helps to continue to remind the public on the excitements involved in carrying out research in basic sciences.
